JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Journal of Radiation Oncology, Biology, Physics

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: A teaching intervention in a contouring dummy run improved target volume delineation in locally advanced non-small cell lung cancer
ArticleInfo.ArticleSubTitle: Reducing the interobserver variability in multicentre clinical studies
ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Verbesserung der Zielvolumendefinition durch einen Dummy Run mit interventionellem Konturierungstraining beim lokal fortgeschrittenen nicht-kleinzelligen Lungenkarzinom
ArticleInfo.ArticleSubTitle: Reduktion der Interobserver-Variabilität in klinischen Multizenterstudien

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Radiation Oncology (MAASTRO), GROW School for Oncology and Developmental Biology
Institute for Medical Biometry and Statistics, Centre for Medical Biometry and Medical Informatics

Affiliation.OrgName: German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ), Heidelberg, Germany and German Cancer Consortium (DKTK) partner site: Freiburg

AbstractSection.Heading: Introduction
AbstractSection.Para: Interobserver variability in the definition of target volumes (TVs) is a well-known confounding factor in (multicentre) clinical studies employing radiotherapy. Therefore, detailed contouring guidelines are provided in the prospective randomised multicentre PET-Plan (NCT00697333) clinical trial protocol. This trial compares strictly FDG-PET-based TV delineation with conventional TV delineation in patients with locally advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Despite detailed contouring guidelines, their interpretation by different radiation oncologists can vary considerably, leading to undesirable discrepancies in TV delineation. Considering this, as part of the PET-Plan study quality assurance (QA), a contouring dummy run (DR) consisting of two phases was performed to analyse the interobserver variability before and after teaching.

AbstractSection.Heading: Materials and methods
AbstractSection.Para: In the first phase of the DR (DR1), radiation oncologists from 14 study centres were asked to delineate TVs as defined by the study protocol (gross TV, GTV; and two clinical TVs, CTV-A and CTV-B) in a test patient. A teaching session was held at a study group meeting, including a discussion of the results focussing on discordances in comparison to the per-protocol solution. Subsequently, the second phase of the DR (DR2) was performed in order to evaluate the impact of teaching.

AbstractSection.Heading: Results
AbstractSection.Para: Teaching after DR1 resulted in a reduction of absolute TVs in DR2, as well as in better concordance of TVs. The Overall Kappa(κ) indices increased from 0.63 to 0.71 (GTV), 0.60 to 0.65 (CTV-A) and from 0.59 to 0.63 (CTV-B), demonstrating improvements in overall interobserver agreement.

AbstractSection.Heading: Conclusion
AbstractSection.Para: Contouring DRs and study group meetings as part of QA in multicentre clinical trials help to identify misinterpretations of per-protocol TV delineation. Teaching the correct interpretation of protocol contouring guidelines leads to a reduction in interobserver variability and to more consistent contouring, which should consequently improve the validity of the overall study results.

AbstractSection.Heading: Einleitung
AbstractSection.Para: Die Interobserver-Variabilität bei der Definition der Zielvolumina („target volumes“, TVs) ist ein anerkanntes Problem in strahlentherapeutischen (multizentrischen) klinischen Studien. In der prospektiven randomisierten multizentrischen PET-Plan-Studie (NCT00697333) wird eine strikt FDG-PET-basierte mit einer konventionellen TV-Definition bei Patienten mit einem lokal fortgeschrittenen nicht-kleinzelligem Lungenkarzinom (NSCLC) verglichen. Im Studienprotokoll ist eine detaillierte Konturierungsanleitung implementiert. Trotz genauer Vorgaben zur TV-Definition kann deren Interpretation durch verschiedene Strahlentherapeuten sehr differieren und zu unerwünschten Diskrepanzen bei den TVs führen. Unter diesem Gesichtspunkt wurde als ein Aspekt der Qualitätssicherungsmaßnahmen der PET-Plan-Studie ein Konturierungs-„Dummy-Run“ in zwei Abschnitten durchgeführt. Analysiert wurde die Interobserver-Variabilität vor und nach einem Konturierungstraining.

AbstractSection.Heading: Material und Methoden
AbstractSection.Para: Im ersten Teil des „Dummy Run“ (DR1) wurden Strahlentherapeuten aus 14 Studienzentren gebeten, eine protokollgemäße Definition der TVs (GTV, CTVA, CTV-B) an einem Beispielpatienten durchzuführen. Bei einem Studientreffen wurden die Ergebnisse mit Fokus auf Diskrepanzen im Vergleich zur protokollgemäßen Konturierung diskutiert. Mit dem Ziel, den Einfluss dieses Konturierungstrainings zu evaluieren, wurde der zweite Teil des „Dummy Run“ (DR2) durchgeführt.

AbstractSection.Heading: Ergebnisse
AbstractSection.Para: Das Training der protokollgemäßen Konturierung nach dem DR1 führte zu einer Reduktion der absoluten Volumina sowie zu einer besseren Übereinstimmung der TVs im DR2. Der „Overall“-Kappa erhöhte sich von 0,63 auf 0,71 (GTV), von 0,60 auf 0,65 (CTV-A) und von 0,59 auf 0,63 (CTV-B).

AbstractSection.Heading: Schlussfolgerung
AbstractSection.Para: Durch Qualitätssicherungsmaßnahmen wie „Dummy Runs“ und Studientreffen können Fehlinterpretationen bei der protokollgemäßen TV-Definition in multizentrischen klinischen Studien in der Strahlenheilkunde identifiziert und durch entsprechendes Training korrigiert werden. Dies sollte sich positiv auf die Validität der Studienergebnisse auswirken.

SimplePara.Emphasis: On behalf of the PET-Plan study group

ArticleNote.Heading: Electronic supplementary material

Body.Para: Lung cancer ranks first in terms of incidence and is also the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide [1]. Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for 80 % of lung tumours and 5-year overall survival is poor [2]. The majority of patients present with advanced-stage disease, for which concurrent chemoradiotherapy is the treatment of choice [3]. The continuous optimisation of radiotherapy—e.g., by reducing target volumes (TVs; [4]), shortening overall treatment times [5], increasing daily fraction doses [6] or escalating doses to metabolically resistant tumour subvolumes [7]—is the objective of several presently accruing clinical trials. With rapidly improving accuracy in treatment delivery and modern radiotherapy techniques, the consistency of TV contouring is of increasing importance.

Diagnostic information from 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron-emission tomography (FDG-PET) is often included in radiation therapy planning process. Due to its high sensitivity and specificity, FDG-PET is routinely used for the diagnosis and staging of NSCLC [8, 9]. FDG-PET has been shown to be the noninvasive method with the highest diagnostic accuracy for nodal staging and can therefore be used to identify involved lymph nodes (LN) in the hilum or mediastinum, facilitating selective nodal irradiation [10, 11]. In addition, the integration of FDG-PET into radiation therapy planning for NSCLC reduces the interobserver variability in TV delineation [12–14]. However, these data were mainly obtained in retrospective studies and a limited number of prospective trials conducted predominantly in the three-dimensional (3D) conformal radiotherapy era. For modern radiotherapy techniques (e.g., intensity-modulated radiation therapy, IMRT; or volumetric-modulated arc therapy, VMAT), targeting of FDG-positive nodal volumes only has not yet been shown to be effective and safe in prospective multicentre cohorts employing combined chemoradiotherapy for locally advanced NSCLC. This is the rationale for the presently recruiting PET-Plan trial (NCT00697333), a prospective randomised multicentre dose escalation trial comparing strictly FDG-PET-based TV delineation with conventional TV delineation in patients with advanced NSCLC [15, 16].

Generally in multicentre clinical trials employing radiotherapy, a detailed delineation guide—as provided in the PET-Plan trial protocol—is the basis for consistency in TVs. Despite detailed contouring instructions, the variability in TVs delineated by different radiation oncologists is a recognised problem. Dummy runs (DRs) for TV delineation of various solid tumours including NSCLC, for both conformal and stereotactic body radiotherapy or in the postoperative setting, have been reported [17–27].

In a study investigating the effect of different TV approaches on outcome and toxicity, delineation according to protocol is crucial. Therefore the quality assurance (QA) program of the PET-Plan trial—besides multicentre phantom calibrations for FDG-PET-based TV definition [28] and radiotherapy review and planning QA—included a two-phase TV contouring DR, on which we report here.

In the context of this DR, we evaluated the impact of joint discussion and teaching on the compliance of the study centres with protocol contouring guidelines by analysing interobserver variability before and after teaching.

Section2.Heading: Patient data and PET/CT image data sets
Section2.Para: The FDG-PET and CT image data sets of a female test patient with a cT2pN3cM0 adenocarcinoma of the right lower lobe were selected for the DR.

The PET scan of the test patient had been acquired in 2009 on a SIEMENS ECAT EXACT 922 scanner (slice thickness 3 mm; Siemens, Forchheim, Germany) and the CT scan on a helical CT scanner (SIEMENS Somatom Emotion 6; Siemens). For the PET scan, the fasting patient was intravenously injected with 495 MBq FDG, adjusted to the patient’s weight. Acquisition of data from the thorax was performed 90 min after tracer injection, extending from the base of the skull to the liver. Attenuation corrections were implemented using a transmission scan and the PET data were reconstructed iteratively. CT and PET scans were acquired on the same day and in the treatment position, with identical positioning during PET and CT scanning verified using radio-opaque markers, a laser coordinate system and photographic documentation.

The primary tumour had a maximum standardised uptake value (SUVmax) of 7.5. FDG-avid LNs were located in the nodal levels 4L (SUVmax 4.7), 7 (SUVmax 4.4) and 10R (SUVmax 4.9). LNs considered pathologically enlarged on CT (short axis > 1 cm) were located in nodal levels 7 and 10R. Histological involvement of LNs in 4L and 7 was verified by mediastinoscopy.

Section2.Heading: PET-Plan contouring guidelines
Section2.Para: According to the PET-Plan protocol, TV contouring is performed using the planning CT coregistered to the planning 3D-FDG-PET scan, both performed in the radiotherapy treatment position. This can be realised by coregistration of two image datasets acquired separately or by using a planning PET/CT. Before contouring, the quality of registration is checked visually at suitable anatomical landmarks. The gross TV (GTV) of the primary tumour is delineated based on the 3D-FDG-PET; preferably using the semiautomatic contrast-oriented algorithm published previously [28, 29]. Manual adjustments enlarging the tumour contour proposed by this algorithm according to CT morphology are allowed.
For the “conventional” study arm A only, a tumour-associated atelectasis is to be included in the GTV up to 3 cm beyond the PET-GTV.
For both study arms, the clinical TV (CTV) of the primary tumour comprises the respective GTV with a 2-mm circumferential margin.

For nodal irradiation, the FDG-positive (focal pathological FDG uptake) and/or CT-positive LNs (short axis diameter > 1 cm), as well as those diagnosed by biopsy are allocated to the respective Mountain–Dressler LN levels and delineated anatomically in accordance with the contouring atlas published by Chapet et al. [30].
In the conventional study arm A, CT and/or PET and/or biopsy positive LN levels are included in the CTV, while in the experimental arm B, only the PET and/or biopsy positives are included (CTV-B).

In both study arms, the primary tumour and the affected LN(s) are subject to isotoxic dose escalation (60–74 Gy). Elective nodal irradiation up to a total dose of 50 Gy is given in study arm A only (CTV-A), including all LN levels with a likelihood of LN metastases greater than 10 %, depending on the location of the primary tumour ([31]; a corresponding table being embodied in the study protocol).
All CTVs are expanded by a margin of 8–10 mm, thus forming the PTVs.

Section2.Heading: Realisation of the dummy run
Section2.Para: The study centres (list of institutions and main responsible persons in appendix 1) were electronically provided with the coregistered FDG-PET and CT Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM) files of the DR test patient, which were to be transferred to the individual radiotherapy treatment planning system of the study centre. For both DR phases, the test patient and DICOM files were identical.

The study centres were provided with CT, PET and biopsy results, and were asked to define TVs using their own radiation treatment planning system: Oncentra Masterplan (Nucletron, Veenendaal, the Netherlands), Eclipse (Varian Medical Systems Inc, Palo Alto, CA, USA) and Pinnacle (Pinnacle Medical Systems, Houston, TX, USA).

TVs based on PET and CT and according to protocol contouring guidelines were: the primary TV (GTV) and the CTVs for each of the two study arms (A and B). In the given DR test patient, due to the absence of atelectasis, the GTVs were similar for both study arms. CTV-A included the primary tumour; the PET- and/or CT- and/or biopsy-positive LN levels 4L, 7 and 10R, as well as the elective LN levels 2R and 4R. CTV-B included the primary tumour and the PET and/or histologically involved LN levels 4L, 7 and 10R.

After delineation of the three DR TVs in the DR phase 1 (DR1), the resulting DR radiotherapy structure sets (RTSS) were to be electronically delivered by the participating study centres and imported into the ARTIVIEW software (AQUILAB SAS, Loos les Lille, France) for analysis.

Section2.Heading: Interventional discussion of results and teaching
Section2.Para: The DR per-protocol solution was demonstrated at a study group meeting and compared with to the DR1 contours provided by the participating study centres. The differences constituted the basis for a teaching discussion with the aim of identifying and correcting misinterpretations of study contouring guidelines, and consequentially clarifying protocol ambiguities.

Within 6 months of the study group meeting, the DR phase two (DR2) was performed as a replication of DR1, in order to evaluate improvements after the teaching intervention described above. In DR2, study centres were asked to recontour the three volumes from scratch; i.e., to conduct the same steps as in DR1, employing the identical test patient and DICOM files.

Section2.Heading: Evaluation methods
Section2.Para: The TVs obtained in DR1 and DR2 were compared using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test (using GraphPad Prism for Macintosh, version 4.0c; GraphPad Software, Inc., La Jolla, CA, USA). The concordance between the volumes (the interobserver agreement) delineated in DR1 and DR2 was evaluated by a generalised Kappa index (Overall Kappa), allowing for measurement of observer agreement for more than two observers, as described by Rücker et al. [32].

Overall Kappa indices are depicted with the lower and upper limits of the 95 % confidence interval (CI), which can be obtained by the normal approximation: lower = κ - 1.96*SE and upper = κ + 1.96*SE, where SE is the standard error. An interpretation of Kappa values was proposed by Landis and Koch [33]. According to this, a Kappa value between 0.41 and 0.60 signifies moderate agreement, a value between 0.61 and 0.80 signifies substantial agreement and a Kappa value between 0.81 and 1.00 signifies almost perfect agreement.

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para: Eight study centres took part in both DR1 and DR2. Additionally, three study centres participated in either one of the DR phases, adding up to a total of 11 study centres participating in DR1 and/or DR2. Representatives of those centres only participating in DR2 were present at the teaching session conducted after DR1. In five instances, the DR1 and DR2 observers within the study centres were not identical. In DR1, the contours from one centre showed complete noncompliance with the protocol contouring guidelines. In order to avoid reporting of an erroneously large improvement of interobserver variability, all contours from this centre in both DR phases were excluded from further analysis. Therefore, 57 out of 60 TVs were available for inclusion in the final analysis (DR1: GTV n = 10, CTV-A n = 10, CTV-B n = 9; DR2: GTV n = 9, CTV-A n = 9, CTV-B n = 10). The three missing TVs had not been contoured by the participating study centres.

Section2.Heading: GTV
Section2.Para:
Comparing DR1 and DR2 for all evaluable study centres, the GTVs had median values of 11.57 cm3 (minimum 6.73 cm3, maximum 20.67 cm3) in DR1 and 11.73 cm3 (range 7.83–19.59 cm3) in DR2. For centres participating in both DR phases (n = 7), the GTVs increased from a median of 11.66 cm3 (range 6.73–20.67 cm3) in DR1 to a median of 12.47 cm3 (8.40–13.86 cm3) in DR2 (p = not significant; Table 1).

As measured by Overall Kappa, the observers showed a good concordance in DR1, which increased after training for all study centres (0.62 in DR1 and 0.71 in DR2), as well as upon consideration of those study centres participating in both DRs only (0.63 in DR1–0.71 in DR2; Table 2 and Fig. 1a).

Section2.Heading: CTV-A
Section2.Para: For all evaluable study centres, median CTV-A values were 119.67 cm3 (86.04–04.69 cm3) in DR1 and 85.37 cm3 (72.56–139.16 cm3) in DR2. For centres participating in both DR phases (n = 7), median CTV-A values were 105.50 cm3 (86.04–167.30 cm3) in DR1 and 102.57 cm3 (72.56–131.16 cm3) in DR2 (p = not significant; Table 1).

The observers showed a good concordance in DR1, which increased after training (Kappa of all study centres: 0.62 in DR1 and 0.64 in DR2); however, this was more pronounced for study centres participating in both DR phases (κ = 0.60 in DR1 and 0.65 in DR2; Table 2).

Section2.Heading: CTV-B
Section2.Para: For all evaluable study centres, median CTV-B values were 93.05 cm3 (71.55–166.49 cm3) in DR1 and 85.37 cm3 (22.18–107.08 cm3) in DR2. For centres participating in both DR phases (n = 7), median CTV-B values were 92.64 cm3 (71.55–132.88 cm3) in DR1 and 92 cm3 (62.11–105.21 cm3) in DR2 (p = not significant ; Table 1).

As measured by Overall Kappa, a good to moderate concordance was found in DR1 for all study centres, which decreased slightly after training (0.61 in DR1 and 0.60 in DR2). Contrastingly, for study centres participating in both DR phases, the Overall Kappa value again increased (from 0.59 in DR1 to 0.63 in DR2; Table 2 and Fig. 1b).

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: One of the most error-prone steps in the radiotherapy planning process—not only in NSCLC—is the delineation of TVs. The perception of this has triggered multiple publications on this issue [17–27]. Consequently, teaching courses focussing primarily on the delineation of the primary tumour have been launched, whereas the definition of guidelines and teaching on the delineation of LNs, both as GTV and CTV, has been somewhat neglected. This has improved since the mid-2000s, fuelled by the trend towards selective nodal irradiation in both small and non-small cell lung cancer, after data were published suggesting a low regional recurrence rate of approximately 2.3–5 % after FDG-PET/CT-based treatment planning of NSCLC [10, 11].

In the German multicentre PET-Plan Study testing the noninferiority of FDG-PET-based selective nodal irradiation in advanced NSCLC, an atlas of CT-based definitions of thoracic LNs published in 2005 was implemented as part of the contouring guidelines [30]. In the present study, we present results underlining the importance of teaching to improve adherence to protocol-specific contouring guidelines by a two phase DR on TV delineation—phase 1 conducted before teaching and phase 2 conducted after teaching.

The overall size of the primary tumour volume (GTV) remained similar in DR1 and DR 2, whereas the nodal volumes CTV-A (incorporating elective nodal irradiation) and CTV-B (selective nodal irradiation) decreased slightly from DR1 to DR2. Having similar sized 3D TVs does not necessarily mean that the 3D TVs also comply with each other. We assumed that the concordance in 3D TVs (i.e., the interobserver agreement) would improve as a result of interventional teaching. Indeed, as measured by Overall Kappa, the interobserver agreement increased after teaching between DR1 to DR2 [32]; although the relatively large standard errors prevented this result from being a statistically significant improvement.

Generally, the Kappa values for the GTV were higher than for CTV-A and CTV-B (Table 2), indicating a better topographic agreement between observers. In contrast to the mediastinal and hilar LN levels, which were to be delineated anatomically, the definition of the primary tumour located in the periphery of the lung seemed to be a task less complex. However, the interobserver agreement from DR1 to DR2 increased considerably more for the GTV than for the CTVs (Fig. 2, Table 2).
Fig. 2
Overall Kappa values, each with lower and upper limits of the 95 % confidence interval (black bars), for gross tumour volume (GTV), and clinical target volumes A and B (CTV-A and CTV-B). Depicted are the results of the seven study centres participating in both dummy runs (DR1 and DR2)

Interestingly, overall GTV sizes were nearly identical in both DRs (Table 1). Visual inspection of the primary TVs showed that before teaching, there was a trend towards including the TV with FDG-uptake only, and not, as per protocol, also the extension of the primary tumour as visualized by CT. Additionally, the demarcation between the GTV and the right hilum was difficult to determine.

Regarding CTVs, the chance of multiple observers disagreeing is obviously greater for larger volumes. This was well illustrated by the generally lower Kappa values for CTV-A and CTV-B. The discussion at the study group meeting revealed that the somewhat different anatomy of the test-case in comparison to the atlas-case triggered some equivocal interpretations of LN level location. This may have been the reason why CTVs in DR1 were considerably larger, as the observers may have tended towards the definition of LN levels with erroneous “security” margins (Fig. 3).
Fig. 3
Comparison of the clinical target volume A contours for lymph node levels 4R/L: the per-protocol solution (CVT-A per protocol) vs. the contours delineated by the study centres in dummy run 1 (CVT-A DR1) visualized in Oncentra Masterplan (Nucletron, Veenendaal, the Netherlands). Contours in red were concordant with the per-protocol solution; contours in yellow were concordant but spaciously delineated and the blue contour was the one excluded from the analysis due to obvious noncompliance with the protocol contouring guidelines

Concerning the delineation of the primary lung tumour and hilar/mediastinal LN levels on CT, van de Steene et al. [26] also found a large interobserver variability among five physicians (two radiation oncologists, one resident radiation oncologist, one radiologist and one pulmonologist). This interobserver variability could be significantly decreased by combining anatomical and functional information, with a simultaneous reduction in the mean number of corrections and the mean delineation time [12, 25].

The need for contouring guidelines was demonstrated by the VU University Medical Centre (VUmc) group [22, 24]. The postoperative CTVs of two cases delineated by six international thoracic radiation oncologists based on (i), routine clinical practice and (ii), the LungART protocol, were assessed. Routine CTVs varied up to three-fold, with a statistically significant reduction using the study protocol. Also, coverage of the LN levels improved based on the protocol, with the exception of the upper paratracheal nodes. The different CTVs inherently lead to large variations in the treatment-associated risk of lung toxicity.

Beyond use of both functional imaging and protocol guidelines, the present analysis shows that additional teaching may further improve the consistency of contouring within a multicentre trial group. The main limitation is the fact that not all study centres participated in both DR phases and that there was a possible change of observers in the centres. In only 5 out of 14 centres, the observers remained identical in the two DR phases. However, this represents the situation in real-life multicentre studies, with a group of persons cooperating at a given trial site and a need to communicate relevant study information. We interpret the fact that the Kappa values still increased as support for the benefit of teaching in this setting too.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Unequivocal contouring guidelines in multicentre clinical studies employing radiotherapy are essential to improve concordance of individual TVs. Beyond this, our data advocate that QA-embedded teaching of TV delineation is a valuable tool for ensuring and improving the adherence to contouring guidelines. This, in turn, reduces interobserver variability and promotes more consistent contouring, which should translate into improved validity of overall study results.

Ethics.Heading: Compliance with ethics guidelines

FormalPara.Heading: Conflict of interest
FormalPara.Para: T. Schimek-Jasch, E.G.C. Troost, G. Rücker, V. Prokic, M. Avlar, V. Duncker-Rohr, M. Mix, C. Doll, A.-L. Grosu and U. Nestle state that there are no conflicts of interest.

Ethics.SimplePara: This study was conducted with the approval of the Ethics Committee of the Albert-Ludwigs-University Freiburg.

All studies on humans described in the present manuscript were carried out with the approval of the responsible ethics committee and in accordance with national law and the Helsinki Declaration of 1975 (in its current, revised form). Informed consent was obtained from all patients included in studies.
Consent was obtained from all patients identifiable from images or other information within the manuscript. In the case of underage patients, consent was obtained from a parent or legal guardian.
